title: 107_s3092
content: The Act titled "Children's Health Protection and Eligibility Act of 2002" allows for the retention and redistribution of SCHIP allotments for fiscal years 1998 through 2000. The Act extends the availability of fiscal years 1998 and 1999 allotments under the Social Security Act to 2003. It also modifies the rule for redistribution and extended availability to allotments for fiscal year 2000. The Act extends the availability of fiscal years 1998 and 1999 allotments under the Social Security Act to 2003 and modifies the rule for redistribution and extended availability to allotments for fiscal year 2000. In clause (i), adjustments are made for fiscal year 2000 by the end of fiscal year 2002. The text discusses adjustments to State's expenditures under the Social Security Act for fiscal years 2000, 2001, and 2002, extending availability of allotments from 1998 and 1999 to 2003, and modifying redistribution rules for fiscal year 2000 allotments. The text discusses adjustments to State's expenditures under the Social Security Act for fiscal years 2000, 2001, and 2002, extending availability of allotments from 1998 and 1999 to 2003, and modifying redistribution rules for fiscal year 2000 allotments by allowing unexpended amounts to remain available for expenditure by the State through the end of fiscal year 2003. In 2003, States with high unemployment rates exceeding 6 percent in consecutive 2 months of 2002 can retain unexpended allotments from fiscal year 2000 for expenditure through the end of fiscal year 2003. States with high unemployment rates exceeding 6 percent in consecutive 2 months of 2002 can retain unexpended allotments from fiscal year 2000 through the end of fiscal year 2003. Amendments made by this section will be effective as if included in the enactment of the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000. States with high unemployment rates exceeding 6 percent in consecutive 2 months of 2002 can retain unexpended SCHIP funds for Medicaid expenditures. States with high unemployment rates exceeding 6 percent in consecutive 2 months of 2002 can elect to use SCHIP funds for Medicaid expenditures for fiscal years 1998 through 2003. For fiscal years 2001 through 2003, qualifying States can receive additional payments under title XIX if they elect the option described in subparagraph (A). The Secretary will pay the State an amount each quarter equal to the additional amount that would have been paid under title XIX for the fiscal year. For fiscal years 2001 through 2003, qualifying States can receive additional payments under title XIX if they elect the option described in subparagraph (A). The Secretary will pay the State an amount each quarter equal to the additional amount that would have been paid under title XIX for the fiscal year. In clause (ii), the enhanced FMAP would replace the Federal medical assistance percentage for expenditures on medical assistance under title XIX for individuals under 19 or pregnant women. Additional payments are permitted for certain states. For fiscal years 2004 and onwards, qualifying States with the highest income eligibility standard as of January 1, 2001, can choose to receive additional payments from the Secretary under subsection (b) or (c) of section 2104. The payments would be equal to the additional amount that would have been paid under title XIX for the State's expenditures. For fiscal years 2004 and onwards, qualifying States with the highest income eligibility standard as of January 1, 2001, can choose to receive additional payments from the Secretary under subsection (b) or (c) of section 2104. The payments would be equal to the additional amount that would have been paid under title XIX for the State's expenditures for providing medical assistance under title XIX to individuals who have not attained age 19 and whose family income exceeds the minimum income eligibility level the State is required to establish. Qualifying States must maintain income eligibility standards for Medicaid and SCHIP since 2001 and not impose waiting lists for children's medical assistance. The State must provide medical assistance to all children who apply and qualify, ensuring no child loses coverage or care due to parents' inability to pay premiums or copayments. The State implements policies and procedures for coverage of children under title XIX and this title, including a simplified application form and elimination of asset tests. The State does not require asset tests for children's eligibility under title XIX or this title. Eligibility is not redetermined more frequently than once a year. The effective date of this amendment is October 1, 2002.
